WHEN King Arthur had after long war rested, and held a royal feast and Table Round with his (Arthur) allies of kings, princes, and noble knights all of the Round Table, there came into his (Arthur) hall, he (Arthur) sitting in his (Arthur) throne royal, twelve ancient men, bearing each of them a branch of olive, in token that they came as ambassadors and messengers from the Emperor Lucius, which was called at that time, Dictator or Procuror of the Public Weal of Rome.

Which said messengers, after their entering and coming into the presence of King Arthur, did to him (King) their obeisance in making to him (King) reverence, and said to him (King) in this wise: The high and mighty Emperor Lucius sendeth to the King of Britain greeting, commanding thee to acknowledge him (King) for thy lord, and to send him (King) the truage due of this realm unto the Empire, which thy father and other to-fore thy precessors have paid as is of record, and thou as rebel not knowing him (rebel) as thy sovereign, withholdest and retainest contrary to the statutes and decrees made by the noble and worthy Julius Cesar, conqueror of this realm, and first Emperor of Rome.

And if thou refuse his (Emperor) demand and commandment know thou for certain that he (Emperor) shall make strong war against thee, thy realms and lands, and shall chastise thee and thy subjects, that it shall be ensample perpetual unto all kings and princes, for to deny their truage unto that noble empire which domineth upon the universal world.

Then when they had showed the effect of their message, the king commanded them to withdraw them, and said he (king) should take advice of council and give to them an answer.

Then some of the young knights, hearing this their message, would have run on them to have slain them, saying that it was a rebuke to all the knights there being present to suffer them to say so to the king.

And anon the king commanded that none of them, upon pain of death, to missay them nor do them any harm, and commanded a knight to bring them to their lodging, and see that they have all that is necessary and requisite for them, with the best cheer, and that no dainty be spared, for the Romans be great lords, and though their message please me not nor my court, yet I must remember mine honour.

After this the king let call all his (king) lords and knights of the Round Table to counsel upon this matter, and desired them to say their advice.

How twelve aged ambassadors of Rome came to King Arthur to demand truage for Britain. Then Sir Cador of Cornwall spake first and said, Sir, this message liketh me well,

for we have many days rested us and have been idle, and now I hope ye shall make sharp war on the Romans, where I doubt not we shall get honour.

I believe well, said Arthur, that this matter pleaseth thee well, but these answers may not be answered, for the demand grieveth me sore, for truly I will never pay truage to Rome, wherefore I pray you to counsel me.

I have understood that Belinus and Brenius, kings of Britain, have had the empire in their hands many days, and also Constantine the son of Heleine, which is an open evidence that we owe no tribute to Rome but of right

we that be descended of them have right to claim the title of the empire. CHAPTER II. How the kings and lords promised to King Arthur aid and help against the Romans.

THEN answered King Anguish of Scotland, Sir, ye ought of right to be above all other kings, for unto you is none like nor pareil in Christendom, of knighthood nor of dignity, and I counsel you never to obey the Romans, for when they reigned on us they distressed our elders, and put this land to great extortions and tallies, wherefore I make here mine avow to avenge me on them; and for to strengthen your quarrel I shall furnish twenty thousand good men of war, and wage them on my costs, which shall await on you with myself when it shall please you.

And then every man agreed to make war, and to aid after their power; that is to wit, the lord of West Wales promised to bring thirty thousand men, and Sir Uwaine, Sir Ider his (lord) son, with their cousins, promised to bring thirty thousand.

And the king of Little Britain granted him (king) to the same thirty thousand; wherefore King Arthur thanked them. Then Sir Launcelot with all other promised in likewise every man a great multitude.

And when King Arthur understood their courages and good wills he (Arthur) thanked them heartily, and after let call the ambassadors to hear their answer.

And in presence of all his (Arthur) lords and knights he (Arthur) said to them in this wise: I will that ye return unto your lord and Procuror of the Common Weal for the Romans, and say ye to him (lord), Of his (lord) demand and commandment I set nothing, and that I know of no truage nor tribute that I owe to him (lord), nor to none earthly prince, Christian nor heathen; but I pretend to have and occupy the sovereignty of the empire, wherein I am entitled by the right of my predecessors, sometime kings of this land; and say to him (Christian) that I am delibered and fully concluded, to go with mine army with strength and power unto Rome, by the grace of God, to take possession in the empire and subdue them that be rebel.

Wherefore I command him (God) and all them of Rome, that incontinent they make to me their homage, and to acknowledge me for their Emperor and Governor, upon pain that shall ensue.

And then he (Governor) commanded his (Governor) treasurer to give to them great and large gifts, and to pay all their dispenses, and assigned Sir Cador to convey them out of the land.

And so they took their leave and departed, and took their shipping at Sandwich, and passed forth by Flanders, Almaine, the mountains, and all Italy, until they came unto Lucius.

When the Emperor Lucius had well understood their credence, he (Lucius) was sore moved as he (Lucius) had been all araged, and said, I had supposed that Arthur would have obeyed to my commandment, and have served you himself, as him (Arthur) well beseemed or any other king to do.

O Sir, said one of the senators, let be such vain words, for we let you wit that I and my fellows were full sore afeard to behold his (Arthur) countenance

; I fear me ye have made a rod for yourself, for he (Arthur) intendeth to be lord of this empire, which sore is to be doubted

if he (lord) come, for he (lord) is all another man than ye ween, and holdeth the most noble court of the world, all other kings nor princes may not compare unto his (lord) noble maintenance.

On New Year's Day we saw him (lord) in his (lord) estate, which was the royalest that ever we saw, for he (lord) was served at his (lord) table with nine kings, and the noblest fellowship of other princes, lords, and knights that be in the world, and every knight approved and like a lord, and holdeth Table Round: and in his (lord) person the most manly man that liveth, and is like to conquer all the world, for unto his (lord) courage it is too little

: wherefore I advise you to keep well your marches and straits in the mountains; for certainly he (lord) is a lord to be doubted.

Well, said Lucius, before Easter I suppose to pass the mountains, and so forth into France, and there bereave him (Lucius) his (Lucius) lands with Genoese and other mighty warriors of Tuscany and Lombardy.

And I shall send for them all that be subjects and allied to the empire of Rome to come to mine aid.

And forthwith sent old wise knights unto these countries following: first to Ambage and Arrage, to Alexandria, to India, to Armenia, whereas the river of Euphrates runneth into Asia, to Africa, and Europe the Large, to Ertayne and Elamye, to Araby, Egypt, and to Damascus, to Damietta and Cayer, to Cappadocia, to Tarsus, Turkey, Pontus and Pamphylia, to Syria and Galatia.

And all these were subject to Rome and many more, as Greece, Cyprus, Macedonia, Calabria, Cateland, Portugal, with many thousands of Spaniards.

And after the reverence made, they made relation of their answer, like as ye to-fore have heard. Thus all these kings, dukes, and admirals, assembled about Rome, with sixteen kings at once, with great multitude of people.

Also he (multitude) had gotten with him (multitude) fifty giants which had been engendered of fiends; and they were ordained to guard his (multitude) person, and to break the front of the battle of King Arthur.

And thus departed from Rome, and came down the mountains for to destroy the lands that Arthur had conquered, and came unto Cologne, and besieged a castle thereby, and won it soon, and stuffed it with two hundred Saracens or Infidels, and after destroyed many fair countries which Arthur had won of King Claudas.

And thus Lucius came with all his (Lucius) host, which were disperplyd sixty mile in breadth, and commanded them to meet with him (Lucius) in Burgoyne, for he (Burgoyne) purposed to destroy the realm of Little Britain.

When the emperor understood their coming he (emperor) made ready his (emperor) Romans and all the people between him (emperor) and Flanders. CHAPTER III.

NOW leave we of Lucius the Emperor and speak we of King Arthur, that commanded all them of his (Arthur) retinue to be ready at the utas of Hilary for to hold a parliament at York.

And at that parliament was concluded to arrest all the navy of the land, and to be ready within fifteen days at Sandwich, and there he (Arthur) showed to his (Arthur) army how he (Arthur) purposed to conquer the empire which he (Arthur) ought to have of right.

And there he (Arthur) ordained two governors of this realm, that is to say, Sir Baudwin of Britain, for to counsel to the best, and Sir Constantine, son to Sir Cador of Cornwall, which after the death of Arthur was king of this realm.

And in the presence of all his (Arthur) lords he (Arthur) resigned the rule of the realm and Guenever his (Arthur) queen to them, wherefore Sir Launcelot was wroth, for he (Arthur) left Sir Tristram with King Mark for the love of Beale Isould.

Thus the king with his (king) great army departed, leaving the queen and realm in the governance of Sir Baudwin and Constantine.

How King Arthur held a parliament at York, and how he (Arthur) ordained the realm should be governed in his (Arthur) absence. And when he (Arthur) was on his (Arthur) horse he (Arthur) said with an high voice,

And after departed and entered into the sea at Sandwich with all his (Constantine) army, with a great multitude of ships, galleys, cogs, and dromounds, sailing on the sea.

CHAPTER IV. How King Arthur being shipped and lying in his (Arthur) cabin had a marvellous dream and of the exposition thereof.

AND as the king lay in his (king) cabin in the ship, he (king) fell in a slumbering and dreamed a marvellous dream: him (king) seemed that a dreadful dragon did drown much of his (king) people, and he (king) came flying out of the west, and his (king) head was enamelled with azure, and his (king) shoulders shone as gold, his (king) belly like mails of a marvellous hue, his (king) tail full of tatters, his (king) feet full of fine sable, and his (king) claws like fine gold; and an hideous flame of fire flew out of his (king) mouth, like as the land and water had flamed all of fire.

After, him (king) seemed there came out of the orient, a grimly boar all black in a cloud, and his (king) paws as big as a post; he (king) was rugged looking roughly, he (king) was the foulest beast that ever man saw, he (king) roared and romed so hideously that it were marvel to hear.

Then the dreadful dragon advanced him (king) and came in the wind like a falcon giving great strokes on the boar, and the boar hit him (king) again with his (king) grizzly tusks that his (king) breast was all bloody, and that the hot blood made all the sea red of his (king) blood.

Then the dragon flew away all on an height, and came down with such a swough, and smote the boar on the ridge, which was ten foot large from the head to the tail, and smote the boar all to powder both flesh and bones, that it flittered all abroad on the sea.

And therewith the king awoke anon, and was sore abashed of this dream, and sent anon for a wise philosopher, commanding to tell him (philosopher) the signification of his (philosopher) dream.

Sir, said the philosopher, the dragon that thou dreamedst of betokeneth thine own person that sailest here, and the colours of his (philosopher) wings be thy realms that thou hast won, and his (philosopher) tail which is all to-tattered signifieth the noble knights of the Round Table; and the boar that the dragon slew coming from the clouds betokeneth some tyrant that tormenteth the people, or else thou art like to fight with some giant thyself, being horrible and abominable, whose peer ye saw never in your days

Then after this soon they had sight of land, and sailed till they arrived at Barflete in Flanders, and when they were there he (tyrant) found many of his (tyrant) great lords ready, as they had been commanded to wait upon him (tyrant).

, wherefore of this dreadful dream doubt thee nothing, but as a conqueror come forth thyself. CHAPTER V. How a man of the country told to him (man) of a marvellous giant, and how he (man) fought and conquered him (man).

And he (Burgoyne) said again, Give the thanks to God, and depart the goods among you. CHAPTER VI. How King Arthur sent Sir Gawaine and other to Lucius, and how they were assailed and escaped with worship.

THEN the king did do call Sir Gawaine, Sir Bors, Sir Lionel, and Sir Bedivere, and commanded them to go straight to Sir Lucius, and say ye to him (Lucius) that hastily he (Lucius) remove out of my land; and if he (Lucius) will not, bid him (Lucius) make him (Lucius) ready to battle and not distress the poor people.

Then anon these noble knights dressed them to horseback, and when they came to the green wood, they saw many pavilions set in a meadow, of silk of divers colours, beside a river, and the emperor's pavilion was in the middle with an eagle displayed above.

To the which tent our knights rode toward, and ordained Sir Gawaine and Sir Bors to do the message, and left in a bushment Sir Lionel and Sir Bedivere.

And then Sir Gawaine and Sir Bors did their message, and commanded Lucius, in Arthur's name to avoid his (Lucius) land, or shortly to address him (Lucius) to battle.

To whom Lucius answered and said, Ye shall return to your lord, and say ye to him (Ye) that I shall subdue him (Ye) and all his (Ye) lands.

Then Sir Gawaine was wroth and said, I had liefer than all France fight against thee; and so had I, said Sir Bors, liefer than all Brittany or Burgoyne.

Then a knight named Sir Gainus, nigh cousin to the emperor, said, Lo, how these Britons be full of pride and boast, and they brag as though they bare up all the world.

And therewith turned their horses and rode over waters and through woods till they came to their bushment, whereas Sir Lionel and Sir Bedivere were hoving.

The Romans followed fast after, on horseback and on foot, over a champaign unto a wood; then Sir Bors turned his (Bors) horse and saw a knight come fast on, whom he (Bors) smote through the body with a spear that he (Bors) fell dead down to the earth; then came Caliburn one of the strongest of Pavie, and smote down many of Arthur's knights.

And when Sir Bors saw him (Bors) do so much harm, he (Bors) addressed toward him (Bors), and smote him (Bors) through the breast, that he (Bors) fell down dead to the earth.

Then Sir Feldenak thought to revenge the death of Gainus upon Sir Gawaine, but Sir Gawaine was ware thereof, and smote him (Gawaine) on the head, which stroke stinted not till it came to his (Gawaine) breast.

Then Sir Gawaine was sore grieved with these words, and pulled out his (Gawaine) sword and smote off his (Gawaine) head. And then he (Gawaine) returned and came to his (Gawaine) fellows in the bushment.

And there was a recounter, for the bushment brake on the Romans, and slew and hew down the Romans, and forced the Romans to flee and return, whom the noble knights chased unto their tents.

Then the Romans gathered more people, and also footmen came on, and there was a new battle, and so much people that Sir Bors and Sir Berel were taken.

Then began the battle to be great, that our knights were in great jeopardy, wherefore Sir Gawaine sent to King Arthur for succour, and that he (Gawaine) hie him (Gawaine), for I am sore wounded, and that our prisoners may pay goods out of number.

And anon the king did do assemble his (king) army, but anon, or he (king) departed the prisoners were come, and Sir Gawaine and his (Gawaine) fellows gat the field and put the Romans to flight, and after returned and came with their fellowship in such wise that no man of worship was lost of them, save that Sir Gawaine was sore hurt.

And thus was the beginning of the first journey of the Britons and Romans, and there were slain of the Romans more than ten thousand, and great joy and mirth was made that night in the host of King Arthur.

And on the morn he (King) sent all the prisoners into Paris under the guard of Sir Launcelot, with many knights, and of Sir Cador.

How Lucius sent certain spies in a bushment for to have taken his (Lucius) knights being prisoners, and how they were letted.

NOW turn we to the Emperor of Rome, which espied that these prisoners should be sent to Paris, and anon he (Emperor) sent to lie in a bushment certain knights and princes with sixty thousand men, for to rescue his (Emperor) knights and lords that were prisoners.

And so on the morn as Launcelot and Sir Cador, chieftains and governors of all them that conveyed the prisoners, as they should pass through a wood, Sir Launcelot sent certain knights to espy if any were in the woods to let them.

And when the said knights came into the wood, anon they espied and saw the great embushment, and returned and told Sir Launcelot that there lay in await for them three score thousand Romans.

And then Sir Launcelot with such knights as he (Emperor) had, and men of war to the number of ten thousand, put them in array, and met with them and fought with them manly, and slew and detrenched many of the Romans, and slew many knights and admirals of the party of the Romans and Saracens; there was slain the king of Lyly and three great lords, Aladuke, Herawd, and Heringdale.

But Sir Launcelot fought so nobly that no man might endure a stroke of his (man) hand, but where he (man) came he (man) showed his (man) prowess and might, for he (man) slew down right on every side; and the Romans and Saracens fled from him (man) as the sheep from the wolf or from the lion, and put them, all that abode alive, to flight.

Then the king wept, and dried his (king) eyes with a kerchief, and said, Your courage had near-hand destroyed you, for though ye had returned again, ye had lost no worship; for I call it folly, knights to abide when they be overmatched.

And after he (king) found three senators which were alive, to whom he (king) said, For to save your lives I will that ye take these dead bodies, and carry them with you unto great Rome, and present them to the Potestate on my behalf, shewing him (king) my letters, and tell them that I in my person shall hastily be at Rome.

And if they be not content with these, I shall pay more at my coming, for other tribute owe I none, nor none other will I pay.

And furthermore, I charge you to say to them, that I command them upon pain of their heads never to demand tribute nor tax of me nor of my lands.

Then with this charge and commandment, the three senators aforesaid departed with all the said dead bodies, laying the body of Lucius in a car covered with the arms of the Empire all alone; and after alway two bodies of kings in a chariot, and then the bodies of the senators after them, and so went toward Rome, and showed their legation and message to the Potestate and Senate, recounting the battle done in France, and how the field was lost and much people and innumerable slain.

BOOK VI. CHAPTER I. How Sir Launcelot and Sir Lionel departed from the court, and how Sir Lionel left him (Lionel) sleeping and was taken.

SOON after that King Arthur was come from Rome into England, then all the knights of the Table Round resorted unto the king, and made many jousts and tournaments, and some there were that were but knights, which increased so in arms and worship that they passed all their fellows in prowess and noble deeds, and that was well proved on many; but in especial it was proved on Sir Launcelot du Lake, for in all tournaments and jousts and deeds of arms, both for life and death, he (king) passed all other knights, and at no time he (king) was never overcome but if it were by treason or enchantment; so Sir Launcelot increased so marvellously in worship, and in honour, therefore is he (king) the first knight that the French book maketh mention of after King Arthur came from Rome.

Wherefore Queen Guenever had him (Arthur) in great favour above all other knights, and in certain he (Arthur) loved the queen again above all other ladies and damosels of his (Arthur) life, and for her (queen) he (Arthur) did many deeds of arms, and saved her (queen) from the fire through his (Arthur) noble chivalry.

And then he (Arthur) thought himself to prove himself in strange adventures, then he (Arthur) bade his (Arthur) nephew, Sir Lionel, for to make him (Arthur) ready; for we two will seek adventures.

So they mounted on their horses, armed at all rights, and rode into a deep forest and so into a deep plain.

And then straight to the third knight he (knight) rode, and smote him (knight) behind his (knight) horse's arse a spear length. CHAPTER II.

WHEN Sir Ector de Maris wist that Sir Launcelot was passed out of the court to seek adventures, he (Maris) was wroth with himself, and made him (Maris) ready to seek Sir Launcelot, and as he (Maris) had ridden long in a great forest he (Maris) met with a man was like a forester.

How Sir Ector followed for to seek Sir Launcelot, and how he (Ector) was taken by Sir Turquine. Fair fellow, said Sir Ector, knowest thou in this country any adventures that be here nigh hand?

Sir, said the forester, this country know I well, and hereby, within this mile, is a strong manor, and well dyked, and by that manor, on the left hand, there is a fair ford for horses to drink of, and over that ford there groweth a fair tree, and thereon hang many fair shields that wielded sometime good knights, and at the hole of the tree hangeth a basin of copper and latten, and strike upon that basin with the butt of thy spear thrice, and soon after thou shalt hear new tidings, and else hast thou the fairest grace that many a year had ever knight that passed through this forest.

And among them he (knight) saw his (knight) brother's shield, Sir Lionel, and many more that he (Lionel) knew that were his (Lionel) fellows of the Round Table, the which grieved his (Lionel) heart, and promised to revenge his (Lionel) brother.

Then anon Sir Ector beat on the basin as he (Ector) were wood, and then he (Ector) gave his (Ector) horse drink at the ford, and there came a knight behind him (knight) and bade him (knight) come out of the water and make him (knight) ready; and Sir Ector anon turned him (knight) shortly, and in feuter cast his (knight) spear, and smote the other knight a great buffet that his (knight) horse turned twice about.

This was well done, said the strong knight, and knightly thou hast stricken me; and therewith he (knight) rushed his (knight) horse on Sir Ector, and cleight him (Ector) under his (Ector) right arm, and bare him (Ector) clean out of the saddle, and rode with him (Ector) away into his (Ector) own hall, and threw him (Ector) down in midst of the floor.

Gramercy, said Sir Ector, and departed and came to the tree, and saw many fair shields. The name of this knight was Sir Turquine.

Then he (knight) said unto Sir Ector, For thou hast done this day more unto me than any knight did these twelve years, now will I grant thee thy life, so thou wilt be sworn to be my prisoner all thy life days.

Nay, said Sir Ector, that will I never promise thee, but that I will do mine advantage. That me repenteth, said Sir Turquine.

And then he (Ector) gart to unarm him (Ector), and beat him (Ector) with thorns all naked, and sithen put him (Ector) down in a deep dungeon, where he (Ector) knew many of his (Ector) fellows.

But when Sir Ector saw Sir Lionel, then made he (Ector) great sorrow. Alas, brother, said Sir Ector, where is my brother Sir Launcelot?

Fair brother, I left him (brother) asleep when that I from him (brother) yode, under an apple-tree, and what is become of him (brother) I cannot tell you.

Alas, said the knights, but Sir Launcelot help us we may never be delivered, for we know now no knight that is able to match our master Turquine.

CHAPTER III How four queens found Launcelot sleeping, and how by enchantment he (knight) was taken and led into a castle. NOW leave we these knights prisoners, and speak we of Sir Launcelot du Lake that lieth under the apple-tree sleeping.

Even about the noon there came by him (knight) four queens of great estate; and, for the heat should not annoy them, there rode four knights about them, and bare a cloth of green silk on four spears, betwixt them and the sun, and the queens rode on four white mules.

Thus as they rode they heard by them a great horse grimly neigh, then were they ware of a sleeping knight

, that lay all armed under an apple-tree; anon as these queens looked on his (knight) face, they knew it was Sir Launcelot.

We shall not strive, said Morgan le Fay, that was King Arthur's sister, I shall put an enchantment upon him (Fay) that he (Fay) shall not awake in six hours, and then I will lead him (Fay) away unto my castle, and when he (Fay) is surely within my hold, I shall take the enchantment from him (Fay), and then let him (Fay) choose which of us he (Fay) will have unto paramour.

So this enchantment was cast upon Sir Launcelot, and then they laid him (Fay) upon his (Fay) shield, and bare him (Fay) so on horseback betwixt two knights, and brought him (Fay) unto the castle Chariot, and there they laid him (Fay) in a chamber cold, and at night they sent unto him (Fay) a fair damosel with his (Fay) supper ready dight.

Then they began for to strive for that knight, everych one said they would have him (knight) to her (Fay) love. By that the enchantment was past, and when she (Fay) came she (Fay) saluted him (knight), and asked him (knight) what cheer.

I cannot say, fair damosel, said Sir Launcelot, for I wot not how I came into this castle but it be by an enchantment.

Sir, said she (Fay), ye must make good cheer, and if ye be such a knight as it is said ye be, I shall tell you more to-morn by prime of the day.

Gramercy, fair damosel, said Sir Launcelot, of your good will I require you. And so she (Fay) departed. And there he (knight) lay all that night without comfort of anybody.

And on the morn early came these four queens, passingly well beseen, all they bidding him (knight) good morn, and he (knight) them again.

Sir knight, the four queens said, thou must understand thou art our prisoner, and we here know thee well that thou art Sir Launcelot du Lake, King Ban's son, and because we understand your worthiness, that thou art the noblest knight living, and as we know

well there can no lady have thy love but one, and that is Queen Guenever, and now thou shalt lose her (Guenever) for ever, and she (Guenever) thee, and therefore thee behoveth now to choose one of us four.

I am the Queen Morgan le Fay, queen of the land of Gore, and here is the queen of Northgalis, and the queen of Eastland, and the queen of the Out Isles; now choose one of us which thou wilt have to thy paramour, for thou mayest not choose or else in this prison to die.

had I liefer to die in this prison with worship, than to have one of you to my paramour maugre my head.

And therefore ye be answered, I will none of you, for ye be false enchantresses, and as for my lady, Dame Guenever, were I at my liberty as I was, I would prove it on you or on yours, that she (lady) is the truest lady unto her (lady) lord living.

This is an hard case, said Sir Launcelot, that either I must die or else choose one of you, yet Well, said the queens, is this your answer, that ye will refuse us.

Yea, on my life, said Sir Launcelot, refused ye be of me. So they departed and left him (lord) there alone that made great sorrow.

CHAPTER IV. How Sir Launcelot was delivered by the mean of a damosel. RIGHT so at the noon came the damosel unto him (lord) with his (lord) dinner, and asked him (lord) what cheer.

Sir, she (I) said, that me repenteth, but an ye will be ruled by me, I shall help you out of this distress, and ye shall have no shame nor villainy, so that ye hold me a promise.

Fair damosel, I will grant you, and sore I am of these queen-sorceresses afeard, for they have destroyed many a good knight.

Sir, said she (I), that is sooth, and for the renown and bounty that they hear of you they would have your love, and Sir, they say, your name is Sir Launcelot du Lake, the flower of knights, and they be passing wroth with you that ye have refused them.

But Sir, an ye would promise me to help my father on Tuesday next coming, that hath made a tournament betwixt him (father) and the King of Northgalis--for the last Tuesday past my father lost the field through three knights of Arthur's court--an ye will be there on Tuesday next coming, and help my father, to-morn or prime, by the grace of God, I shall deliver you clean.

Truly, fair damosel, said Sir Launcelot, in my life days never so ill. Fair maiden, said Sir Launcelot, tell me what is your father's name, and then shall I give you an answer.

I know your father well, said Sir Launcelot, for a noble king and a good knight, and by the faith of my body, ye shall have my body ready to do your father and you

Sir knight, she (I) said, my father is King Bagdemagus, that was foul rebuked at the last tournament. service at that day.

and I shall be she (I) that shall deliver you and take you your armour and your horse, shield and spear, and hereby within this ten mile, is an abbey of white monks

CHAPTER V. How a knight found Sir Launcelot lying in his (knight) leman's bed, and how Sir Launcelot fought with the knight.

Then came into the field King Bagdemagus with four score of helms. CHAPTER VII. How Sir Launcelot behaved him (King) in a tournament, and how he (King) met with Sir Turquine leading Sir Gaheris.

That is overmuch said, said Sir Launcelot. CHAPTER VIII. How Sir Launcelot and Sir Turquine fought together. And so within a while they had both grimly wounds, and bled passing grievously.

CHAPTER IX. How Sir Turquine was slain, and how Sir Launcelot bade Sir Gaheris deliver all the prisoners. THEN at the last Sir Turquine waxed faint, and gave somewhat aback, and bare his (they) shield low for weariness.

How Sir Launcelot rode with a damosel and slew a knight that distressed all ladies and also a villain that kept a bridge.

Sir, said the damosel, here by this way haunteth a knight that distressed all ladies and gentlewomen, and at the least he (knight) robbeth them or lieth by them.

CHAPTER X. NOW turn we unto Sir Launcelot, that rode with the damosel in a fair highway. What, said Sir Launcelot, is he (knight) a thief and a knight and a ravisher of women?

But, fair damosel, ye shall ride on afore, yourself, and I will keep myself in covert, and if that he (knight) trouble you or distress you

he (knight) doth shame unto the order of knighthood, and contrary unto his (knight) oath; it is pity that he (knight) liveth. I shall be your rescue and learn him (knight) to be ruled as a knight.

So the maid rode on by the way a soft ambling pace, and within a while came out that knight on horseback out of the wood, and his (knight) page with him (knight), and there he (knight) put the damosel from her (maid) horse, and then she (maid) cried.

With that came Launcelot as fast as he (knight) might till he (knight) came to that knight, saying, O thou false knight and traitor unto knighthood, who did learn thee to distress ladies and gentlewomen?

When the knight saw Sir Launcelot thus rebuking him (knight) he (knight) answered not, but drew his (knight) sword and rode unto Sir Launcelot, and Sir Launcelot threw his (knight) spear from him (knight), and drew out his (knight) sword, and struck him (knight) such a buffet on the helmet that he (knight) clave his (knight) head and neck unto the throat.

Now hast thou thy payment that long thou hast deserved! That is truth, said the damosel, for like as Sir Turquine watched to destroy knights,

so did this knight attend to destroy and distress ladies, damosels, and gentlewomen, and his (knight) name was Sir Peris de Forest Savage.

Nay, sir, she (Turquine) said, at this time, but almighty Jesu preserve you wheresomever ye ride or go, for the curteist knight thou art, and meekest unto all ladies and gentlewomen, that now liveth.

Now, damosel, said Sir Launcelot, will ye any more service of me? But one thing, sir knight, methinketh ye lack, ye that are a knight wifeless

, that he (knight) will not love some maiden or gentlewoman, for I could never hear say that ever ye loved any of no manner degree, and that is great pity; but it is noised that ye love Queen Guenever, and that she (Guenever) hath ordained by enchantment that ye shall never love none other but her (Guenever), nor none other damosel nor lady shall rejoice you; wherefore many in this land, of high estate and low, make great sorrow.

Fair damosel, said Sir Launcelot, I may not warn people to speak of me what it pleaseth them; but for to be a wedded man, I think it not; for then I must couch with her (lady), and leave arms and tournaments, battles, and adventures; and as for to say for to take my pleasaunce with paramours, that will I refuse in principal for dread of God; for knights that be adventurous or lecherous shall not be happy nor fortunate unto the wars, for other they shall be overcome with a simpler knight than they be themselves, other else they shall by unhap and their cursedness slay better men than they be themselves.

And so who that useth paramours shall be unhappy, and all thing is unhappy that is about them. And so Sir Launcelot and she (their) departed.

So on the third day he (knight) rode over a long bridge, and there stert upon him (knight) suddenly a passing foul churl, and he (knight) smote his (knight) horse on the nose that he (knight) turned about, and asked him (knight) why he (knight) rode over that bridge without his (knight) licence.

And then he (knight) rode in a deep forest two days and more, and had strait lodging. Why should I not ride this way? said Sir Launcelot, I may not ride beside.

Thou shalt not choose, said the churl, and lashed at him (knight) with a great club shod with iron. Then Sir Launcelot drew his (knight) sword and put the stroke aback, and clave his (knight) head unto the paps.

At the end of the bridge was a fair village, and all the people, men and women, cried on Sir Launcelot, and said, A worse deed didst thou never for thyself, for thou hast slain the chief porter of our castle.

Sir Launcelot let them say what they would, and straight he (chief) went into the castle; and when he (chief) came into the castle he (chief) alighted, and tied his (chief) horse to a ring on the wall and there he (chief) saw a fair green court, and thither he (chief) dressed him (chief), for there him (chief) thought was a fair place to fight in.

So he (chief) looked about, and saw much people in doors and windows that said, Fair knight, thou art unhappy. CHAPTER XI.

ANON withal came there upon him (knight) two great giants, well armed all save the heads, with two horrible clubs in their hands.

Sir Launcelot put his (knight) shield afore him (knight) and put the stroke away of the one giant, and with his (knight) sword he (knight) clave his (knight) head asunder.

When his (knight) fellow saw that, he (knight) ran away as he (knight) were wood, for fear of the horrible strokes, and Launcelot after him (knight) with all his (knight) might, and smote him (knight) on the shoulder, and clave him (knight) to the navel.

Then Sir Launcelot went into the hall, and there came afore him (knight) three score ladies and damosels, and all kneeled unto him (knight), and thanked God and him (God) of their deliverance; For sir, said they, the most party of us have been here this seven year their prisoners, and we have worked all manner of silk works for our meat, and we are all great gentlewomen born; and blessed be the time, knight, that ever thou be born, for thou hast done the most worship that ever did knight in this world, that will we bear record, and we all pray you to tell us your name, that we may tell our friends who delivered us out of prison.

How Sir Launcelot slew two giants, and made a castle free. Fair damosel, he (knight) said, my name is Sir Launcelot du Lake.

Ah, sir, said they all, well mayest thou be he (knight), for else save yourself, as we deemed, there might never knight have the better of these two giants; for many fair knights have assayed it, and here have ended, and many times have we wished after you, and these two giants dread never knight but you.

Now may ye say, said Sir Launcelot, unto your friends how and who hath delivered you, and greet them all from me, and if that I come in any of your marches, show me such cheer as ye have cause, and what treasure that there in this castle is I give it you for a reward for your grievance, and the lord that is owner of this castle I would he (lord) received it as is right.

Fair sir, said they, the name of this castle is Tintagil, and a duke ought it sometime that had wedded fair Igraine, and after wedded her (your) Uther Pendragon, and gat on her (your) Arthur.

Well, said Sir Launcelot, I understand to whom this castle longeth; and so he (Arthur) departed from them, and betaught them unto God.

And then he (God) mounted upon his (God) horse, and rode into many strange and wild countries, and through many waters and valleys, and evil was he (God) lodged.

And at the last by fortune him (God) happened, against a night, to come to a fair courtelage, and therein he (God) found an old gentlewoman that lodged him (God) with good will, and there he (God) had good cheer for him (God) and his (God) horse.

Fair damosel, give me goodly language, and then my care is past, for what knights somever they be, I care not, nor I doubt them not.

Also, said she (lady), I say it for thine avail, yet mayest thou turn again with thy worship; for an thou follow me, thou art but slain, for I see all that ever thou dost is but by misadventure, and not by prowess of thy hands.

Well, damosel, ye may say what ye will, but wheresomever ye go I will follow you. So this Beaumains rode with that lady till evensong time, and ever she (lady) chid him (thy), and would not rest.

And they came to a black laund; and there was a black hawthorn, and thereon hung a black banner, and on the other side there hung a black shield, and by it stood a black spear great and long, and

For I dare say there was never gentlewoman reviled man in so foul a manner as I have rebuked him (man); and at all times he (man) gave me goodly and meek answers again.

And as they sat thus talking, there came Sir Gareth in at the gate with an angry countenance, and his (Gareth) sword drawn in his (Gareth) hand, and cried aloud that all the castle might hear it, saying: Thou traitor, Sir Gringamore, deliver me my dwarf again, or by the faith that I owe to the order of knighthood, I shall do thee all the harm that I can.

Then Sir Gringamore looked out at a window and said, Sir Gareth of Orkney, leave thy boasting words, for thou gettest not thy dwarf again.

Thou coward knight, said Sir Gareth, bring him (Gareth) with thee, and come and do battle with me, and win him (Gareth) and take him (Gareth).

And also, brother, he (brother) hath done much for me, and delivered me from the Red Knight of the Red Launds, and therefore, brother, I owe him (brother) my service afore all knights living.

I keep no more of the dwarf. And wit ye well that I love him (dwarf) before all other, and full fain

I would speak with him (dwarf). But in nowise I would that he (dwarf) wist what I were, but that I were another strange lady.

And right therewithal he (dwarf) went down unto Sir Gareth, and said: Sir, I cry you mercy, and all that I have misdone I will amend it at your will.

And therefore I pray you that ye would alight, and take such cheer as I can make you in this castle.

Well, said Sir Gringamore, sithen I know now your will, I will obey now unto him (Gareth). Shall I have my dwarf? said Sir Gareth.

Yea, sir, and all the pleasaunce that I can make you, for as soon as your dwarf told me what ye were and of what blood ye are come, and what noble deeds ye have done in these marches, then I repented of my deeds.

And then Sir Gareth alighted, and there came his (Gareth) dwarf and took his (dwarf) horse. O my fellow, said Sir Gareth, I have had many adventures for thy sake.

CHAPTER XXVII. AND then there came with King Arthur Sir Gawaine, Agravaine, Gaheris, his (King) brethren. : all these came with King Arthur, and more that cannot be rehearsed.

Now leave we of these kings and knights, and let us speak of the great array that was made within the castle and about the castle for both parties.

The Lady Dame Lionesse ordained great array upon her (Lionesse) part for her (Lionesse) noble knights, for all manner of lodging and victual that came by land and by water, that there lacked nothing for her (Lionesse) party, nor for the other, but there was plenty to be had for gold and silver for King Arthur and his (King) knights.

And then there came the harbingers from King Arthur for to harbour him (King), and his (King) kings, dukes, earls, barons, and knights.

And then Sir Gareth prayed Dame Lionesse and the Red Knight of the Red Launds, and Sir Persant and his (Knight) brother, and Sir Gringamore, that in no wise there should none of them tell not his (Knight) name, and make no more of him (Knight) than of the least knight that there was, For, he (knight) said, I will not be known of neither more nor less, neither at the beginning neither at the ending.

Sir, I will lend you a ring, but I would pray you as you love me heartily let me have it again when the tournament is done, for that ring increaseth my beauty much more than it is of himself.

And the virtue of my ring is that, that is green it will turn to red, and that is red it will turn in likeness to green, and that is blue it will turn to likeness of white, and that is white it will turn in likeness to blue, and so it will do of all manner of colours.

Then Dame Lionesse said unto Sir Gareth: Also who that beareth my ring shall lose no blood, and for great love I will give you this ring.

Gramercy, said Sir Gareth, mine own lady, for this ring is passing meet for me, for it will turn all manner of likeness that I am in, and that shall cause me that I shall not be known.

Then Sir Gringamore gave Sir Gareth a bay courser that was a passing good horse; also he (Gareth) gave him (Gareth) good armour and sure, and a noble sword that sometime Sir Gringamore's father won upon an heathen tyrant.

And so thus every knight made him (knight) ready to that tournament. And King Arthur was come two days to-fore the Assumption of our Lady.

And there was all manner of royalty of all minstrelsy that might be found. Also there came Queen Guenever and the Queen of Orkney, Sir Gareth's mother.

And upon the Assumption Day, when mass and matins were done, there were heralds with trumpets commanded to blow to the field.

And so there came out Sir Epinogrus, the king's son of Northumberland, from the castle, and there encountered with him (king) Sir Sagramore le Desirous, and either of them brake their spears to their hands.

And then came in Sir Palamides out of the castle, and there encountered with him (king) Gawaine, and either of them smote other so hard that both the good knights and their horses fell to the earth.

And then came in Sir Safere and Sir Segwarides, brethren to Sir Palamides; and there encountered Sir Agravaine with Sir Safere and Sir Gaheris encountered with Sir Segwarides.

Then came in Sir Carados of the dolorous tower, and Sir Turquine, knights of the castle; and there encountered with them Sir Percivale de Galis and Sir Lamorak de Galis, that were two brethren.

And there encountered Sir Percivale with Sir Carados, and either brake their spears unto their hands, and then Sir Turquine with Sir Lamorak, and either of them smote down other's horse and all to the earth, and either parties rescued other, and horsed them again.

And Sir Arnold and Sir Gauter, knights of the castle, encountered with Sir Brandiles and Sir Kay, and these four knights encountered mightily, and brake their spears to their hands.

Then came in Sir Tristram, Sir Sadok, and Sir Dinas, knights of the castle, and there encountered Sir Tristram with Sir Bedivere, and there Sir Bedivere was smitten to the earth both horse and man.

CHAPTER XXXI. The porter answered ungoodly again, and said, Thou gettest no lodging here. Then she (duchess) yode up into a tower over the gate, with great torchlight.

And as the book saith, he (harper) began good measures of blowing of beasts of venery, and beasts of chase, and all manner of vermin, and all these terms we have yet of hawking and hunting.

Wherefore, as meseemeth, all gentlemen that bear old arms ought of right to honour Sir Tristram for the goodly terms that gentlemen have and use, and shall to the day of doom, that thereby in a manner all men of worship may dissever a gentleman from a yeoman, and from a yeoman a villain.

And therefore the book of venery, of hawking, and hunting, is called the book of Sir Tristram. For he (yeoman) that gentle is will draw him (yeoman) unto gentle tatches, and to follow the customs of noble gentlemen.

Thus Sir Tristram endured in Cornwall until he (Tristram) was big and strong, of the age of eighteen years. And then the King Meliodas had great joy of Sir Tristram, and so had the queen, his (Tristram) wife.

CHAPTER IV. How Sir Marhaus came out of Ireland for to ask truage of Cornwall, or else he (Tristram) would fight therefore.

THEN it befell that King Anguish of Ireland sent unto King Mark of Cornwall for his (King) truage, that Cornwall had paid many winters.

And King Mark and his (King) barons gave unto the messenger of Ireland these words and answer, that they would none pay; and bade the messenger go unto his (King) King Anguish, and tell him (King) we will pay him (King) no truage, but tell your lord, an he (King) will always have truage of us of Cornwall, bid him (King) send a trusty knight of his (King) land, that will fight for his (King) right, and we shall find another for to defend our right.

And all that time King Mark was behind of the truage for seven years. With this answer the messengers departed into Ireland.

And then he (Mark) called unto him (Mark) Sir Marhaus, the good knight, that was nobly proved, and a Knight of the Table Round.

And when King Anguish understood the answer of the messengers he (King) was wonderly wroth. And this Marhaus was brother unto the queen of Ireland.

Then the king said thus: Fair brother, Sir Marhaus, I pray you go into Cornwall for my sake, and do battle for our truage that of right we ought to have; and whatsomever ye spend ye shall have sufficiently, more than ye shall need.

Sir, said Marhaus, wit ye well that I shall not be loath to do battle in the right of you and your land with the best knight of the Table Round;

for I know them, for the most part, what be their deeds; and for to advance my deeds and to increase my worship I will right gladly go unto this journey for our right.

So in all haste there was made purveyance for Sir Marhaus, and he (knight) had all things that to him (knight) needed; and so he (knight) departed out of Ireland, and arrived up in Cornwall even fast by the Castle of Tintagil.

And when King Mark understood that he (Mark) was there arrived to fight for Ireland, then made King Mark great sorrow when he (King) understood that the good and noble knight Sir Marhaus was come.

For they knew no knight that durst have ado with him (knight). For at that time Sir Marhaus was called one of the famousest and renowned knights of the world.

And thus Sir Marhaus abode in the sea, and every day he (knight) sent unto King Mark for to pay the truage that was behind of seven year, other else to find a knight to fight with him (knight) for the truage.

Then they of Cornwall let make cries in every place, that what knight would fight for to save the truage of Cornwall, he (knight) should be rewarded so that he (knight) should fare the better, term of his (knight) life.

Then some of the barons said to King Mark, and counselled him (King) to send to the court of King Arthur for to seek Sir Launcelot du Lake, that was that time named for the marvelloust knight of all the world.

Then there were some other barons that counselled the king not to do so, and said that it was labour in vain, because Sir Marhaus was a knight of the Round Table, therefore any of them will be loath to have ado with other, but if it were any knight at his (knight) own request would fight disguised and unknown.

So the king and all his (king) barons assented that it was no bote to seek any knight of the Round Table.

This mean while came the language and the noise unto King Meliodas, how that Sir Marhaus abode battle fast by Tintagil, and how King Mark could find no manner knight to fight for him (King).

When young Tristram heard of this he (King) was wroth, and sore ashamed that there durst no knight in Cornwall have ado with Sir Marhaus of Ireland.

This manner of message Sir Marhaus sent daily unto King Mark. CHAPTER V. How Tristram enterprized the battle to fight for the truage of Cornwall, and how he (King) was made knight.

Sithen that he (King) saith so, let him (King) wit that I am come of father side and mother side of as noble blood as he (King) is: for, sir, now shall ye know that I am King Meliodas' son, born of your own sister, Dame Elizabeth, that died in the forest in the birth of me.

Then in all the haste the king let horse Sir Tristram, and armed him (Tristram) in the best manner that might be had or gotten for gold or silver.

And then King Mark sent unto Sir Marhaus, and did him (King) to wit that a better born man than he (King) was himself should fight with him (King), and his (King) name is Sir Tristram de Liones, gotten of King Meliodas, and born of King Mark's sister.

Then said Sir Tristram: O Jesu, said King Mark, ye are welcome fair nephew to me. Then was Sir Marhaus glad and blithe that he (King) should fight with such a gentleman.

And so by the assent of King Mark and of Sir Marhaus they let ordain that they should fight within an island nigh Sir Marhaus' ships; and so was Sir Tristram put into a vessel both his (Tristram) horse and he (Tristram), and all that to him (Tristram) longed both for his (Tristram) body and for his (Tristram) horse.

And when King Mark and his (King) barons of Cornwall beheld how young Sir Tristram departed with such a carriage to fight for the right of Cornwall, there was neither man nor woman of worship

Sir Tristram lacked nothing. but they wept to see and understand so young a knight to jeopardy himself for their right.

SO to shorten this tale, when Sir Tristram was arrived within the island he (Tristram) looked to the farther side, and there he (Tristram) saw at an anchor six ships nigh to the land; and under the shadow of the ships upon the land, there hoved the noble knight, Sir Marhaus of Ireland.

Then Sir Tristram commanded his (Tristram) servant Gouvernail to bring his (Tristram) horse to the land, and dress his (Tristram) harness at all manner of rights.

Then they began to feutre their spears, and they met so fiercely together that they smote either other down, both horse and all.

But Sir Marhaus smote Sir Tristram a great wound in the side with his (Knight) spear, and then they avoided their horses, and pulled out their swords, and threw their shields afore them.

And when they had stricken so together long, then they left their strokes, and foined at their breaths and visors; and when they saw that that might not prevail them, then they hurtled together like rams to bear either other down.

Thus they fought still more than half a day, and either were wounded passing sore, that the blood ran down freshly from them upon the ground.

By then Sir Tristram waxed more fresher than Sir Marhaus, and better winded and bigger; and with a mighty stroke he (Tristram) smote Sir Marhaus upon the helm such a buffet that it went through his (Tristram) helm, and through the coif of steel, and through the brain-pan, and the sword stuck so fast in the helm and in his (Tristram) brain-pan that Sir Tristram pulled thrice at his (Tristram) sword or ever he (Tristram) might pull it out from his (Tristram) head; and there Marhaus fell down on his (Tristram) knees, the edge of Tristram's sword left in his (Tristram) brain-pan.

And suddenly Sir Marhaus rose grovelling, and threw his (Tristram) sword and his (Tristram) shield from him (Tristram), and so ran to his (Tristram) ships and fled his (Tristram) way, and Sir Tristram had ever his (Tristram) shield and his (Tristram) sword.

And then they lashed together as men that were wild and courageous. And when Sir Tristram saw Sir Marhaus withdraw him (Tristram), he (Tristram) said: Ah!

thou dost thyself and thy kin great shame, for I am but a young knight, or now I was never proved, and rather than I should withdraw me from thee, I had rather be hewn in an hundred pieces.

Sir Knight of the Round Table, why withdrawest thou thee? Sir Marhaus answered no word but yede his (Knight) way sore groaning.

Well, Sir Knight, said Sir Tristram, I promise thee thy sword and thy shield shall be mine; and thy shield shall I wear in all places where I ride on mine adventures, and in the sight of King Arthur and all the Round Table.

For, as the French book saith, the spear's head was envenomed, that Sir Tristram might not be whole. Thus said the lady unto the king.

CHAPTER IX. How Sir Tristram was put to the keeping of La Beale Isoud first for to be healed of his (Tristram) wound.

And at that time Sir Palamides, the Saracen, was in that country, and well cherished with the king and the queen.

And wit you well Thus was there great envy betwixt Tramtrist and Sir Palamides. And what man won her (Lady), three days after he (man) should wed her (Lady) and have all her (Lady) lands.

Madam, said Tramtrist, as for that, it may be so, for he (knight) is a proved knight, and I am but a young knight and late made; and the first battle that I did it mishapped me to be sore wounded as ye see.

But an I wist ye would be my better lady, at that tournament I will be, so that ye will keep my counsel and let no creature have knowledge that I shall joust but yourself, and such as ye will to keep your counsel, my poor person shall I jeopard there for your sake, that, peradventure, Sir Palamides shall know when that I come.

Thereto, said La Beale Isoud, do your best, and as I can, said La Beale Isoud, I shall purvey horse and armour for you at my device.

Ah, Tramtrist, said La Beale Isoud, why will ye not have ado at that tournament? well I wot As ye will so be it, said Sir Tramtrist, I will be at your commandment.

CHAPTER XII. How Sir Tristram departed from the king and La Beale Isoud out of Ireland for to come into Cornwall.

SIR, said Tristram, now I shall tell you all the truth: my father's name is Sir Meliodas, King of Liones, and my mother hight Elizabeth, that was sister unto King Mark of Cornwall; and my mother died of me in the forest, and because thereof she (mother) commanded, or she (mother) died, that when I were christened they should christen me Tristram; and because I would not be known in this country

I turned my name and let me call Tramtrist; and for the truage of Cornwall I fought for my eme's sake, and for the right of Cornwall that ye had posseded many years.

And wit ye well, said Tristram unto the king, I did the battle for the love of mine uncle, King Mark, and for the love of the country of Cornwall, and for to increase mine honour; for that same day that I fought with Sir Marhaus I was made knight, and never or then did I battle with no knight, and from me he (knight) went alive, and left his (knight) shield and his (knight) sword behind.

So God me help, said the king, I may not say but ye did as a knight should, and it was your part to do for your quarrel, and to increase your worship as a knight should

; howbeit I may not maintain you in this country with my worship, unless that I should displease my barons, and my wife and her (wife) kin.

Sir, said Tristram, I thank you of your good lordship that I have had with you here, and the great goodness my lady, your daughter, hath shewed me, and

therefore, said Sir Tristram, it may so happen that ye shall win more by my life than by my death, for in the parts of England

I may do you service at some season, that ye shall be glad that ever ye shewed me your good lordship.

Also I beseech your good grace that I may take my leave at my lady, your daughter, and at all the barons and knights.

it may happen I will well, said the king. Then Sir Tristram went unto La Beale Isoud and took his (Tristram) leave of her (Isoud).

NOW make your answer that your champion is ready, for I shall die in your quarrel rather than to be recreant.

I have no doubt of you, said the king, that, an ye should have ado with Sir Launcelot du Lake-- Sir, said Sir Tristram, as for Sir Launcelot, he (Tristram) is called the noblest knight of the world, and wit ye well that the knights of his (Tristram) blood are noble men, and dread shame; and as for Bleoberis, brother unto Sir Blamore, I have done battle with him (Blamore), therefore upon my head it is no shame to call him (Blamore) a good knight.

Sir, as for that let him (knight) be, he (knight) shall never be refused, an as he (knight) were the best knight that now beareth shield or spear.

So King Anguish departed unto King Carados and the kings that were that time as judges, and told them that he (King) had found his (King) champion ready.

Then by the commandment of the kings Sir Blamore de Ganis and Sir Tristram were sent for to hear the charge.

And when they were come before the judges there were many kings and knights beheld Sir Tristram, and much speech they had of him (Tristram) because that he (Tristram) slew Sir Marhaus, the good knight, and because he (knight) for-jousted Sir Palamides the good knight.

It is noised, said the king, that Blamore is the hardier knight. So when they had taken their charge they withdrew them to make them ready to do battle.

Fair dear brother, remember of what kin we be come of, and what a man is Sir Launcelot du Lake, neither farther nor nearer but brother's children, and there was never none of our kin that ever was shamed in battle; and rather suffer death, brother, than to be shamed.

Brother, said Blamore, have ye no doubt of me, for I shall never shame none of my blood; howbeit I am sure that yonder knight is called a passing good knight as of his (knight) time one of the world, yet shall I never yield me, nor say the loath word: well may he (knight) happen to smite me down with his (knight) great might of chivalry, but rather shall he (knight) slay me than I shall yield me as recreant.

God speed you well, said Sir Bleoberis, for ye shall find him (Bleoberis) the mightiest knight that ever ye had ado withal, for I know him (knight), for I have had ado with him (knight).

God me speed, said Sir Blamore de Ganis; and therewith he (Ganis) took his (Ganis) horse at the one end of the lists, and Sir Tristram at the other end of the lists, and

so they feutred their spears and came together as it had been thunder; and there Sir Tristram through great might smote down Sir Blamore and his (Blamore) horse to the earth.

Then anon Sir Blamore avoided his (Blamore) horse and pulled out his (Blamore) sword and threw his (Blamore) shield afore him (Blamore), and bade Sir Tristram alight:

Then said Sir Bleoberis unto his (Bleoberis) brother, Sir Blamore: For though an horse hath failed me, I trust to God the earth will not fail me.

And then Sir Tristram alighted, and dressed him (Tristram) unto battle; and there they lashed together strongly as racing and tracing, foining and dashing, many sad strokes, that the kings and knights had great wonder that they might stand; for ever they fought like wood men, so that there was never knights seen fight more fiercely than they did; for Sir Blamore was so hasty that he (Blamore) would have no rest, that all men wondered that they had breath to stand on their feet; and all the place was bloody that they fought in.

And at the last, Sir Tristram smote Sir Blamore such a buffet upon the helm that he (Blamore) there fell down upon his (Blamore) side, and Sir Tristram stood and beheld him (Tristram).

CHAPTER XXIII. How Sir Blamore desired Tristram to slay him (Blamore), and how Sir Tristram spared him (Tristram), and how they took appointment.

THEN when Sir Blamore might speak, he (Blamore) said thus: Sir Tristram de Liones, I require thee, as thou art a noble knight, and the best knight that ever I found, that thou wilt slay me out, for I would not live to be made lord of all the earth, for I have liefer die with worship than live with shame; and needs, Sir Tristram, thou must slay me, or else thou shalt never win the field, for I will never say the loath word.

When Sir Tristram heard him (Tristram) say so knightly, he (Tristram) wist not what to do with him (Tristram); he (Tristram) remembering him (Tristram) of both parties, of what blood he (Tristram) was come, and for Sir Launcelot's sake he (Tristram) would be loath to slay him (Tristram); and in the other party in no wise he (Tristram) might not choose, but that he (Tristram) must make him (Tristram) to say the loath word, or else to slay him (Tristram).

Then Sir Tristram stert aback, and went to the kings that were judges, and there he (Tristram) kneeled down to-fore them, and besought them for their worships, and for King Arthur's and Sir Launcelot's sake, that they would take this matter in their hands.

For, my fair lords, said Sir Tristram, it were shame and pity that this noble knight that yonder lieth should be slain; for ye hear well, shamed will he (Tristram) not be,

And therefore if thou dare slay me, slay me, I require thee. and I pray to God that he (God) never be slain nor shamed for me.

And as for the king for whom I fight for, I shall require him (king), as I am his (king) true champion and true knight in this field, that he (king) will have mercy upon this good knight.

So God me help, said King Anguish, I will for your sake; Sir Tristram, be ruled as ye will have me, for I know you for my true knight; and therefore I will heartily pray the kings that be here as judges to take it in their hands.

My lords, said Bleoberis, though my brother be beaten, and hath the worse through might of arms, I dare say, though Sir Tristram hath beaten his (Tristram) body he (Tristram) hath not beaten his (Tristram) heart, and I thank God he (God) is not shamed this day; and rather than he (God) should be shamed

And the kings that were judges called Sir Bleoberis to them, and asked him (Bleoberis) his (Bleoberis) advice. I require you, said Bleoberis, let Sir Tristram slay him (Tristram) out.

It shall not be so, said the kings, for his (Tristram) part adversary, both the king and the champion, have pity of Sir Blamore's knighthood.

My lords, said Bleoberis, I will right well as ye will. Then the kings called the King of Ireland, and found him (King) goodly and treatable.

And then, by all their advices, Sir Tristram and Sir Bleoberis took up Sir Blamore, and the two brethren were accorded with King Anguish, and kissed and made friends for ever.

And then Sir Blamore and Sir Tristram kissed together, and there they made their oaths that they would never none of them two brethren fight with Sir Tristram, and Sir Tristram made the same oath.

And for that gentle battle all the blood of Sir Launcelot loved Sir Tristram for ever. Then King Anguish and Sir Tristram took their leave, and sailed into Ireland with great noblesse and joy.

So when they were in Ireland the king let make it known throughout all the land how and in what manner Sir Tristram had done for him (Tristram).

But the joy that La Beale Isoud made of Sir Tristram there might no tongue tell, for of all men earthly she (Isoud) loved him (Tristram) most.

CHAPTER XXV. THUS as Sir Tristram and La Beale Isoud were in prison , it happed a knight and a lady came unto them where they were, to cheer them.

CHAPTER XXVII. How Sir Galahad fought with Sir Tristram, and how Sir Tristram yielded him (Tristram) and promised to fellowship with Launcelot.

THEN came Sir Galahad, and the King with the Hundred Knights with him (Tristram); and this Sir Galahad proffered to fight with Sir Tristram hand for hand.

Then Sir Galahad and Sir Tristram met together so hard that either bare other down, horse and all, to the earth.

And then they avoided their horses as noble knights, and dressed their shields, and drew their swords with ire and rancour, and they lashed together many sad strokes, and one

while striking, another while foining, tracing and traversing as noble knights; thus they fought long, near half a day, and either were sore wounded.

At the last Sir Tristram waxed light and big, and doubled his (Tristram) strokes, and drove Sir Galahad aback on the one side and on the other, so that he (Tristram) was like to have been slain.

And so they made them ready to go unto battle on horseback with great courage. With that came the King with the Hundred Knights, and all that fellowship went fiercely upon Sir Tristram.

When Sir Tristram saw them coming upon him (Tristram), then he (Tristram) wist well he (Tristram) might not endure. Then as a wise knight of war, he (Tristram) said to Sir Galahad, the haut prince:

Sir, ye show to me no knighthood, for to suffer all your men to have ado with me all at once; and as meseemeth ye be a noble knight of your hands it is great shame to you.

So God me help, said Sir Galahad, there is none other way but thou must yield thee to me, other else to die, said Sir Galahad to Sir Tristram.

I will rather yield me to you than die for that is more for the might of your men than of your hands.

And therewithal Sir Tristram took his (Tristram) own sword by the point, and put the pommel in the hand of Sir Galahad.

Let be, said Sir Galahad, be ye not so hardy to touch him (Tristram), for I have given this knight his (knight) life.

Therewithal came the King with the Hundred Knights, and hard began to assail Sir Tristram. That is your shame, said the King with the Hundred Knights; hath he (King) not slain your father and your mother?

As for that, said Sir Galahad, I may not wite him (King) greatly, for my father had him (father) in prison, and enforced him (father) to do battle with him (father); and my father had such a custom that was a shameful custom, that what knight came there to ask harbour his (knight) lady must needs die

but if she (lady) were fairer than my mother; and if my father overcame that knight he (father) must needs die. This was a shameful custom and usage, a knight for his (knight) harbour-asking to have such harbourage.

And for this custom I would never draw about him (knight). So God me help, said the King, this was a shameful custom.

Truly, said Sir Galahad, so seemed me; and meseemed it had been great pity that this knight should have been slain, for I dare say he (knight) is the noblest man that beareth life, but if it were Sir Launcelot du Lake.

Now, fair knight, said Sir Galahad, I require thee tell me thy name, and of whence thou art, and whither thou wilt.

I shall promise you never in all my days shall such customs be used in this castle as have been used.

Sir, he (Tristram) said, my name is Sir Tristram de Liones, and from King Mark of Cornwall Sir, said Sir Tristram, now I let you wit, so God me help

I shall abide you, said La Beale Isoud. Notwithstanding, half against her (Isoud) will, she (Isoud) went with Sir Palamides unto the queen.

And when the queen saw her (queen) she (queen) was passing glad. Now, Madam, said Palamides, remember upon your promise, for I have fulfilled my promise.

Sir Palamides, said the queen, I wot not what is your desire, but I will that ye wit, howbeit I promised you largely, I thought none evil, nor I warn you none evil will I do.

Madam, said Sir Palamides, as at this time, ye shall not know my desire, but before my lord your husband there shall ye know that I will have my desire that ye have promised me.

And when Sir Palamides came before the king, he (king) said: Sir King, I require you as ye be a righteous king, that ye will judge me the right.

And therewith the queen departed, and rode home to the king, and Sir Palamides rode after her (queen). Tell me your cause, said the king, and ye shall have right.

CHAPTER XXX. How Palamides demanded Queen Isoud, and how Lambegus rode after to rescue her (Isoud), and of the escape of Isoud.

SIR, said Palamides, I promised your Queen Isoud to bring again Dame Bragwaine that she (Queen) had lost, upon this covenant, that she (Queen) should grant me a boon that I would ask, and without grudging, outher advisement, she (Queen) granted me.

It is as he (king) saith, so God me help, said the queen; to say thee sooth I promised him (king) his (king) asking for love and joy that I had to see her (queen).

Then, said Palamides, I will that ye wit that I will have your queen to lead her (queen) and govern her (queen) whereas me list.

What say ye, my lady? said the king. ye perform your promise. Therewith the king stood still, and bethought him (king) of Sir Tristram, and deemed that he (Tristram) would rescue her (queen).

And so, to make short tale, Sir Palamides took her (queen) by the hand and said: Madam, grudge not to go with me, for I desire nothing but your own promise.

As for that, said the queen, I fear not greatly to go with thee, howbeit thou hast me at advantage upon my promise, for I doubt not I shall be worshipfully rescued from thee.

As for that, said Palamides, I dare right well abide the adventure. As for that, said Sir Palamides, be it as it be may.

Alas, said the king, now I am shamed for ever, that by mine own assent my lady and my queen shall be devoured.

Gramercy, said the king, as I live, Sir Lambegus, I shall deserve it. And then Sir Lambegus armed him (king), and rode after as fast as he (king) might.

And then within a while he (king) overtook Sir Palamides. And then Sir Palamides left the queen. What art thou, said Palamides, art thou Tristram?

Nay, he (king) said, I am his (king) servant, and my name is Sir Lambegus. That me repenteth, said Palamides. I had liefer thou hadst been Sir Tristram.

And then they hurtled together and all to-brast their spears, and then they pulled out their swords, and hewed on helms and hauberks.

he (knight) nist where. Wit ye well Sir Palamides was never so heavy. And when he (knight) found the queen in that mischief he (knight) rescued her (queen), and brought her (queen) to his (knight) castle.

Well ye know I will be ruled by you. Madam, said Sir Tristram, I will leave fighting at this time for your sake.

CHAPTER XXXIII. How Sir Lamorak jousted with thirty knights, and Sir Tristram at the request of King Mark smote his (Tristram) horse down.

THE king and the queen made their pavilions and their tents in that forest beside a river, and there was daily hunting and jousting, for there were ever thirty knights ready to joust unto all them that came in at that time.

And there by fortune came Sir Lamorak de Galis and Sir Driant; and there Sir Driant jousted right well, but at the last he (Galis) had a fall.

And when he (Galis) began he (Galis) fared so with the thirty knights that there was not one of them but that he (Galis) gave him (Galis) a fall, and some of them were sore hurt.

Then Sir Lamorak proffered to joust. I marvel, said King Mark, what knight he (Mark) is that doth such deeds of arms.

As for that, said King Mark, I require you, as ye love me and my lady the queen, La Beale Isoud, take your arms and joust with Sir Lamorak de Galis.

As for the shame, said Sir Lamorak, on thy part or on mine, bear thou it an thou wilt, for though a mare's son hath failed me, now a queen's son shall not fail thee; and therefore, an thou be such a knight as men call thee

How Sir Lamorak sent an horn to King Mark in despite of Sir Tristram, and how Sir Tristram was driven into a chapel.

And then Sir Tristram was received worshipfully with procession. Then King Howel embraced him (Tristram) in his (Howel) arms, and said: Sir Tristram, all my kingdom I will resign to thee.

Then by the great means of King Howel and Kehydius his (Howel) son, by great proffers, there grew great love betwixt Isoud and Sir Tristram, for that lady was both good and fair, and a woman of noble blood and fame.

And for because Sir Tristram had such cheer and riches, and all other pleasaunce that he (Tristram) had, almost he (Tristram) had forsaken La Beale Isoud.

God defend, said Sir Tristram, for I am beholden unto you for your daughter's sake to do for you. And so upon a time Sir Tristram agreed to wed Isoud la Blanche Mains.

And at the last they were wedded, and solemnly held their marriage. And so when they were abed both Sir Tristram remembered him (Tristram) of his (Tristram) old lady La Beale Isoud.

And then he (Tristram) took such a thought suddenly that he (Tristram) was all dismayed, and other cheer made he (Tristram) none but with clipping and kissing; as for other fleshly lusts Sir Tristram never thought nor had ado with her (Isoud): such mention maketh the French book; also it maketh mention that the lady weened there had been no pleasure but kissing and clipping.

, his (Tristram) name was Suppinabiles, and he (Tristram) came over the sea into England, and then he (Tristram) came into the court of King Arthur, and there he (King) met with Sir Launcelot du Lake, and told him (King) of the marriage of Sir Tristram.

Fie upon him (King), untrue knight to his (knight) lady, that so noble a knight as Sir Tristram is should be found to his (knight) first lady false, La Beale Isoud, Queen of Cornwall; but say ye him (knight) this, said Sir Launcelot, that of all knights in the world I loved him (knight) most, and had most joy of him (knight), and all was for his (knight) noble deeds; and let him (knight) wit the love between him (knight) and me is done for ever, and that I give him (knight) warning from this day forth as his (knight) mortal enemy.

That me repenteth, said Tristram, for of all knights I loved to be in his (Tristram) fellowship. And the lord of that isle, hight Sir Nabon le Noire, a great mighty giant.

That forthinketh me, said Sir Lamorak, for that knight's death, for he (Lamorak) was my cousin; and if I were at mine ease as well as ever I was, I would revenge his (Lamorak) death.

Peace, said the fishers, and make here no words, for or ever ye depart from hence Sir Nabon must know that ye have been here, or else we should die for your sake.

IN the meantime there came word that Sir Nabon had made a cry that all the people of that isle should be at his (Lamorak) castle the fifth day after.

And the same day the son of Nabon should be made knight, and all the knights of that valley and thereabout should be there to joust, and all those of the realm of Logris should be there to joust with them of North Wales: and thither came five hundred knights, and they of the country brought thither Sir Lamorak, and Sir Tristram, and Sir Kehydius, and Sir Segwarides, for they durst none otherwise do; and then Sir Nabon lent Sir Lamorak horse and armour at Sir Lamorak's desire, and Sir Lamorak jousted and did such deeds of arms that Nabon and all the people said there was never knight that ever they saw do such deeds of arms; for, as the French book saith, he (Lamorak) for-jousted all that were there, for the most part of five hundred knights, that none abode him (Lamorak) in his (Lamorak) saddle.

CHAPTER XXXIX. How Sir Tristram fought with Sir Nabon, and overcame him (Tristram), and made Sir Segwarides lord of the isle. Then Sir Nabon proffered to play with him (Tristram) his (Tristram) play:

For I saw never no knight do so much upon a day. I will well, said Sir Lamorak, play as I may, but I am weary and sore bruised.

Then when Sir Tristram heard that, he (Tristram) stepped forth and said: Nabon, lend me horse and sure armour, and I will have ado with thee.

Well, fellow, said Sir Nabon, go thou to yonder pavilion, and arm thee of the best thou findest there, and I shall play a marvellous play with thee.

Then said Sir Tristram: Look ye play well, or else peradventure I shall learn you a new play. That is well said, fellow, said Sir Nabon.

So when Sir Tristram was armed as him (Tristram) liked best, and well shielded and sworded, he (Tristram) dressed to him (Tristram) on foot; for well he (Tristram) knew that Sir Nabon would not abide a stroke with a spear, therefore he (Tristram) would slay all knights' horses.

Now, fair fellow, Sir Nabon, let us play. So then they fought long on foot, tracing and traversing, smiting and foining long without any rest.
