How a young man came into the court of King Arthur, and how Sir Kay called him (Kay) in scorn La Cote Male Taile.

AT the court of King Arthur there came a young man and bigly made, and he (man) was richly beseen: and he (man) desired to be made knight of the king, but his (man) over-garment sat over-thwartly, howbeit it was rich cloth of gold.

And here beginneth the history of La Cote Male Taile. BOOK IX. CHAPTER I. What is your name? said King Arthur.

Sir, said he (Arthur), my name is Breunor le Noire, and within short space ye shall know that I am of good kin.

It may well be, said Sir Kay, the Seneschal, but in mockage ye shall be called La Cote Male Taile, that is as much to say, the evil-shapen coat

It is a great thing that thou askest, said the king; and for what cause wearest thou that rich coat? tell me, for I can well think for some cause it is.

Sir, he (king) answered, I had a father, a noble knight, and as he (king) rode a-hunting, upon a day it happed him (king) to lay him (king) down to sleep; and there came a knight that had been long his (knight) enemy, and when he (knight) saw he (knight) was fast asleep

he (knight) all to-hew him (knight); and this same coat had my father on the same time; and that maketh this coat to sit so evil upon me, for the strokes be on it as I found it, and never shall be amended for me.

Thus to have my father's death in remembrance I wear this coat till I be revenged; and because ye are called the most noblest king of the world

Sir, said Sir Lamorak and Sir Gaheris, it were well done to make him (Lamorak) knight; for him (Lamorak) beseemeth well of person and of countenance, that he (Lamorak) shall prove a good man, and a good knight, and a mighty; for, Sir, an ye be remembered, even such one was Sir Launcelot du Lake when he (knight) came first into this court, and full few of us knew from whence he (knight) came; and now is he (knight) proved the man of most worship in the world; and all your court and all your Round Table is by Sir Launcelot worshipped and amended more than by any knight now living.

I come to you that ye should make me knight. That is truth, said the king, and to-morrow at your request I shall make him (king) knight.

So on the morrow there was an hart found, and thither rode King Arthur with a company of his (King) knights to slay the hart.

And this young man that Sir Kay named La Cote Male Taile was there left behind with Queen Guenever; and by sudden adventure there was an horrible lion kept in a strong tower of stone, and it happened that he (Kay) at that time brake loose, and came hurling afore the queen and her (queen) knights.

And when the queen saw the lion she (queen) cried and fled, and prayed her (queen) knights to rescue her (queen). And there was none of them all but twelve that abode, and all the other fled.

Now I see well that all coward knights be not dead; and therewithal he (coward) drew his (coward) sword and dressed him (coward) afore the lion.

And he (coward) then smote him (coward) in the midst of the head such a mighty stroke that it clave his (coward) head in sunder, and dashed to the earth.

Then was it told the queen how the young man that Sir Kay named by scorn La Cote Male Taile had slain the lion.

Then said La Cote Male Taile: And that lion gaped wide and came upon him (Taile) ramping to have slain him (Taile). With that the king came home.

And when the queen told him (king) of that adventure, he (king) was well pleased, and said: Upon pain of mine head he (king) shall prove a noble man and a faithful knight, and true of his (knight) promise: then the king forthwithal made him (knight) knight.

Now Sir, said this young knight, I require you and all the knights of your court, that ye call me by none other name

but La Cote Male Taile : in so much as Sir Kay hath so named me so will I be called.

How a damosel came into the court and desired a knight to take on him (knight) an enquest, which La Cote Male Taile emprised.

THEN that same day there came a damosel into the court, and she (Kay) brought with her (Kay) a great black shield, with a white hand in the midst holding a sword.

I assent me well thereto, said the king. CHAPTER II. Other picture was there none in that shield. When King Arthur saw her (Kay) he (Arthur) asked her (Kay) from whence

Sir, she (Kay) said, I have ridden long and many a day with this shield many ways, and for this cause I am come to your court: there was a good knight that ought this shield, and this knight had undertaken a great deed of arms to enchieve it; and so it misfortuned him (knight) another strong knight met with him (knight) by sudden adventure, and there they fought long, and either wounded other passing sore; and they were so weary that they left that battle even hand.

In such a place, said Sir Fergus. Then Sir Fergus found Queen Isoud sick in her (Isoud) bed, making the greatest dole that ever any earthly woman made.

And there by fortune the damosel met with Sir Tristram again, making the greatest dole that ever earthly creature made; and she (Isoud) yede to the lady of that castle and told her (Isoud) of the misadventure of Sir Tristram.

Right here by your castle, said the damosel. So this lady and damosel brought him (Tristram) meat and drink, but he (Tristram) ate little thereof.

Thus he (Tristram) there endured a quarter of a year. Then at the last he (Tristram) ran his (Tristram) way, and she (lady) wist not where he (Tristram) was become.

And then was he (Tristram) naked and waxed lean and poor of flesh; and so he (Tristram) fell in the fellowship of herdmen and shepherds, and daily they would give him (Tristram) some of their meat and drink.

And when he (Tristram) did any shrewd deed they would beat him (Tristram) with rods, and so they clipped him (Tristram) with shears and made him (Tristram) like a fool.

How Sir Tristram soused Dagonet in a well, and how Palomides sent a damosel to seek Tristram, and how Palomides met with King Mark.

AND upon a day Dagonet, King Arthur's fool, came into Cornwall with two squires with him (King); and as they rode through that forest they came by a fair well where Sir Tristram was wont to be; and the weather was hot, and they alighted to drink of that well, and in the meanwhile their horses brake loose.

Right so Sir Tristram came unto them, and first he (Tristram) soused Sir Dagonet in that well, and after his (Tristram) squires, and thereat laughed the shepherds; and forthwithal he (Tristram) ran after their horses and brought them again one by one, and right so, wet as they were, he (Tristram) made them leap up and ride their ways.

The meanwhile the damosel that Sir Palomides sent to seek Sir Tristram, she (Tristram) yede unto Sir Palomides and told him (Tristram) all the mischief that Sir Tristram endured.

Alas, said Sir Palomides, it is great pity that ever so noble a knight should be so mischieved for the love of a lady; but nevertheless, I will go and seek him (Tristram), and comfort him (Tristram) an I may.

CHAPTER XIX. Thus Sir Tristram endured there an half year naked, and would never come in town nor village. Then a little before that time La Beale Isoud had commanded Sir Kehydius out of the country of Cornwall.

So Sir Kehydius departed with a dolorous heart, and by adventure he (Tristram) met with Sir Palomides, and they enfellowshipped together; and either complained to other of their hot love that they loved La Beale Isoud.

Now let us, said Sir Palomides, seek Sir Tristram, that loved her (Isoud) as well as we, and let us prove whether we may recover him (Tristram).

So they rode into that forest, and three days and three nights they would never take their lodging, but ever sought Sir Tristram.

And upon a time, by adventure, they met with King Mark that was ridden from his (Mark) men all alone. When they saw him (Mark) Sir Palomides knew him (Mark), but Sir Kehydius knew him (Mark) not.

Ah, false king, said Sir Palomides, it is pity thou hast thy life, for thou art a destroyer of all worshipful knights, and by thy mischief and thy vengeance thou hast destroyed that most noble knight, Sir Tristram de Liones.

And therefore defend thee, said Sir Palomides, for thou shalt die this day. That were shame, said King Mark, for ye two are armed and I am unarmed.

As for that, said Sir Palomides, I shall find a remedy therefore; here is a knight with me, and thou shalt have his (knight) harness.

Nay, said King Mark, I will not have ado with you, for cause have ye none to me; for all the misease that Sir Tristram hath was for a letter that he (Tristram) found; for as to me I did to him (Tristram) no displeasure, and God knoweth I am full sorry for his (God) disease and malady.

So when the king had thus excused him (king) they were friends, and King Mark would have had them unto Tintagil; but Sir Palomides would not, but turned unto the realm of Logris, and Sir Kehydius said that he (Mark) would go into Brittany.

Greet well King Mark and all mine enemies, and say them I will come again when I may; and well am I rewarded for the fighting with Sir Marhaus, and delivered all this country from servage; and well am I rewarded for the fetching and costs of Queen Isoud out of Ireland, and the danger that I was in first and last, and by the way coming home what danger I had to bring again Queen Isoud from the Castle Pluere; and well am I rewarded when I fought with Sir Bleoberis for Sir Segwarides' wife; and well am I rewarded when I fought with Sir Blamore de Ganis for King Anguish, father unto La Beale Isoud; and well am I rewarded when I smote down the good knight, Sir Lamorak de Galis, at King Mark's request; and well am I rewarded when I fought with the King with the Hundred Knights, and the King of Northgalis, and both these would have put his (King) land in servage, and by me they were put to a rebuke; and well am I rewarded for the slaying of Tauleas, the mighty giant, and many other deeds

Ye shall be right welcome, said then Sir Tristram. have I done for him (Tristram), and now have I my warison. And forthwithal he (Tristram) took the sea.

CHAPTER XXIII. How a damosel sought help to help Sir Launcelot against thirty knights, and how Sir Tristram fought with them.

AND at the next landing, fast by the sea, there met with Sir Tristram and with Sir Dinadan, Sir Ector de Maris and Sir Bors de Ganis; and there Sir Ector jousted with Sir Dinadan, and he (Ector) smote him (Ector) and his (Ector) horse down.

And then Sir Tristram would have jousted with Sir Bors, and Sir Bors said that he (Tristram) would not joust with no Cornish knights, for they are not called men of worship; and all this was done upon a bridge.

And with this came Sir Bleoberis and Sir Driant, and Sir Bleoberis proffered to joust with Sir Tristram, and there Sir Tristram smote down Sir Bleoberis.

I wist never Cornish knight of so great valour nor so valiant as that knight that beareth the trappings embroidered with crowns.

And then Sir Tristram and Sir Dinadan departed from them into a forest, and there met them a damosel that came for the love of Sir Launcelot to seek after some noble knights of King Arthur's court for to rescue Sir Launcelot.

And so Sir Launcelot was ordained, for-by the treason of Queen Morgan le Fay to have slain Sir Launcelot, and for that cause she (knight) ordained thirty knights to lie in await for Sir Launcelot, and this damosel knew this treason.

And so this damosel met with Sir Bors and Sir Ector and with Sir Driant, and there she (knight) told them all four of the treason of Morgan le Fay; and then they promised her (knight) that they would be nigh where Sir Launcelot should meet with the thirty knights.

For that night, or the day after, Sir Launcelot should come where these thirty knights were. And if so be they set upon him (Fay) we will do rescues as we can.

So the damosel departed, and by adventure the damosel met with Sir Tristram and with Sir Dinadan, and there the damosel told them all the treason that was ordained for Sir Launcelot.

it is not for us to fight with thirty knights, and wit you well I will not thereof; as to match one knight two or three is enough an they be men, but for to match fifteen knights that will I never undertake.

What will ye do? Fie for shame, said Sir Tristram, do but your part. Nay, said Sir Dinadan, I will not thereof

ye be ever forborne. Nay, said Sir Tristram, I will not depart from my shield for her (ye) sake that gave it me.

CHAPTER XXIV. How Sir Tristram and Sir Dinadan came to a lodging where they must joust with two knights. but if he (Tristram) joust with two knights, and if he (Tristram) be but one knight he (Tristram) must joust with two.

And as ye be therein soon shall ye be matched. There is shrewd harbour, said Sir Dinadan; lodge where ye will, for I will not lodge there.

Fie for shame, said Sir Tristram, are ye not a knight of the Table Round? wherefore ye may not with your worship refuse your lodging.

Not so, said the herdmen, for an ye be beaten and have the worse ye shall not be lodged there, and if ye beat them ye shall be well harboured.

Then Sir Dinadan would not lodge there in no manner but as Sir Tristram required him (Tristram) of his (Tristram) knighthood; and so they rode thither.

And when they were unarmed, and thought to be merry and in good rest, there came in at the gates Sir Palomides and Sir Gaheris, requiring to have the custom of the castle.

Ah, said Sir Dinadan, they are two sure knights. What array is this? said Sir Dinadan, I would have my rest.

That may not be, said Sir Tristram; now must we needs defend the custom of this castle, insomuch as we have the better of the lords of this castle, and therefore, said Sir Tristram, needs must ye make you ready.

And so they made them ready; and Sir Gaheris encountered with Sir Tristram, and Sir Gaheris had a fall; and Sir Palomides encountered with Sir Dinadan, and Sir Dinadan had a fall: then was it fall for fall.

In the devil's name, said Sir Dinadan, came I into your company. So then must they fight on foot. That would not Sir Dinadan, for he (devil) was so sore bruised of the fall that Sir Palomides gave him (devil).

Then without any tarrying Sir Darras put Sir Tristram, and Sir Palomides, and Sir Dinadan, within a strong prison, and there Sir Tristram was like to have died of great sickness; and every day Sir Palomides would reprove Sir Tristram of old hate betwixt them.

Ah sir, said the damosel, that same is he (Tristram) that slew your three sons. And ever Sir Tristram spake fair and said little.

But when Sir Palomides saw the falling of sickness of Sir Tristram, then was he (Tristram) heavy for him (Tristram), and comforted him (Tristram) in all the best wise he (Tristram) could.

And as the French book saith, there came forty knights to Sir Darras that were of his (Tristram) own kin, and they would have slain Sir Tristram and his (Tristram) two fellows, but Sir Darras would not suffer that, but kept them in prison, and meat and drink they had.

So Sir Tristram endured there great pain, for sickness had undertaken him (Tristram), and that is the greatest pain a prisoner may have.

For all the while a prisoner may have his (prisoner) health of body he (prisoner) may endure under the mercy of God and in hope of good deliverance; but when sickness toucheth a prisoner's body, then may a prisoner say all wealth is him (prisoner) bereft, and then he (prisoner) hath cause to wail and to weep.

Right so did Sir Tristram when sickness had undertaken him (Tristram), for then he (Tristram) took such sorrow that he (Tristram) had almost slain himself.

Then ever Sir Tristram smote down knights wonderly to behold, what upon the right hand and upon the left hand, that unnethe no knight might withstand him (knight).

And ever Sir Arthur's eye was on that shield. All that espied the queen, and that made her (queen) sore afeard. And the King of Scots and the King of Ireland began to withdraw them.

When Arthur espied that, he (Arthur) thought that that knight with the strange shield should not escape him (Arthur). Then he (Arthur) called unto him (Arthur) Sir Uwaine le Blanche Mains, and bade him (Arthur) arm him (Arthur) and make him (Arthur) ready.

So anon King Arthur and Sir Uwaine dressed them before Sir Tristram, and required him (Arthur) to tell them where he (Arthur) had that shield.

So here endeth this history of this book, for it is the first book of Sir Tristram de Liones and the second book of Sir Tristram followeth.
